justice demands that my sins be punished and I can't bear it. So that's my dilemma. Right. The
solution comes with Jesus. And so the problem with any other, for example, religious leader,
Gandhi or Muhammad or Buddha, anybody, they all have the same problem I have of sin. Even
Mother Teresa, you know, always pick her up. She's the one that you can always say, I'm no Mother
Teresa, but I'm no Hitler. Like you're always in the middle of the tube, but they all have the same
problem. And so that's what makes Jesus unique in that he's the only one who didn't have my same
problem. And God provided him as this substitute, yeah, sinless life, sin, bearing death in my place
that he offers as a free gift, which is what Christmas is all about. The, the, the argument
against Christianity because it's exclusive has always been interesting to me in that we, we,
we, it's based on the assumption that God must not have an opinion on these things. And so the idea
of, of religion, if, if religion is everybody, so if I told you guys I wanted to buy flowers for
Ginger and said, what do you think I should get her? I mean, y'all's opinions are equally invalid.
I'm not buying them for you. I'm buying them for her. And so unless you've got some kind of
supernatural insight into her preferences, you're going to be wrong. I mean, if you say,
if you go, man, roses, that's what my wife likes best. Like, well, that's great. I'm not,
it's not her I'm buying flowers for. And it's just intriguing to me that, that we take that
right from God, that God doesn't get to have preferences and priorities. God doesn't get to
say, no, no, I'm God. So you worship me this way. If religion is just everybody guessing
at what kind of flowers to buy God, then yeah, everybody's opinion is equally valid slash invalid.
But if God has said, these are the kind of flowers I like, well, then those are the kind of flowers
we probably ought to get him. And so if God says, if humans are coming up with it, then yeah,
every route is just as good as every other route. Meaning they're all worthless, because we're just
humans. But, but if God actually has an opinion, then what we've got to do is evaluate the claims
about God's opinions to see what of those makes sense or founded in truth and are reliable, etc.
And so that that God gets to see if God says, listen, this is the way to me. And this is the
only way that I accept or this is the, this is the only thing I'm looking for, or, or even if it's
just this is the way I'm telling you about, even if there are others, I'm only giving you one.
Like if you even no matter how God comes at it, if he comes at it like that,
well, that that's a claim that that he's the one who gets to decide and us saying, well, but
exclusivity, that doesn't seem, that doesn't seem fair, you know, but that's, that's okay. I'm the,
he's the one we're trying to please. And so he's the one who knows again, it's like telling
Colonel Colter, it's not fair that I can't point the pointy in at me and pull the trigger. Like,
I mean, I'm just telling you that's going to get you killed. And so for God to say, no,
this is the way to me, this is the way to write relationship with me. I'm not going with any
others. This it's this one. Well, that certainly is prerogative, isn't it? I mean, it's, it's,
I'm allowed to tell people how to approach me. I'm allowed to have boundaries on how you love me
or serve me or whatever. I'm allowed to do that. Every human is. It's just fascinating that we
would strip God of that option, that God doesn't get to have boundaries and God doesn't get to have
perspectives and opinions. And God doesn't get to have what he's drawn out as the way.
And that's the nature of truth. Truth just by its definition is going to be exclusive
in that it's just any other options. Two plus two is four and three or five are just wrong answers.
And that's exclusive. And that's the nature of it. That's your name is Colson. And I could be
sincerely, I've been sincerely wrong about people's names before. Colston. Yeah. Or I call you Coleman
since I worked with Coleman Ross. But it just, it just means it's the nature of truth. And so
even like your flower illustration, on a different note, if the doctor tells you you have cancer,
you don't get to decide, okay, well, so a spoonful of sugar every day, that's what I want. That'll
cure my cancer. Sorry. You don't get to pick that. Like that's, this is not, you could do that,
but you'd be wrong. It won't help your cancer. And so in the same way, I need to know, okay,
what does God say my, my malady is, and then what does God say is the cure? What did he provide?
Is the solution that I use the illustration here about the party. I wanted you to come to my party.
I don't think so. Okay.
Don't sound familiar. Yeah. If you get an invitation from me that said,
Hey, I'm having a birthday party, uh, Friday night and the directions to my house were when
you leave the church parking lot, um, you can head South on 69 or North on 69. It's up to you.
And you can travel, I don't know, as many miles as you want. And then turn on
right or left on any street that you like, pick the best house that you see there. And you're at
my party and anyone right away would go, no, I'm not. That doesn't work that way. It doesn't work
that way. And so I've not heard this one. The point is it, if I gave you those directions,
it actually doesn't sound like I really want you at my party. Right. Exactly. That's a good way
to say it. But if I'm very specific, like turn right, not left, go 3.5 miles. Here's my actual
address on this street. That sounds like I want you at my party. And so when God gives us very
particular directions on here is how you get to my party in heaven, the banquet, the big eternal,
you know, wow, awesome place. It's because he wants you there.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you heard
or were challenged, please leave us a review. We'll help other people find us. If you have
questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org.
Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up,
trust God, search for answers.
